texts.definition: Pre-created events and challenges that can be used to provide content for game sessions.
markups: <style="Definition">Pre-created events and challenges that can be used to provide content for game sessions.</style>

Some games describe game worlds and possible actions within them but do not specify exact settings and events that players are to encounter, instead having these be things that can be varied between game sessions and game instances. While these can be improvised in some games and procedurally generated in other, <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> are pre-created collections of settings, events, and characters that can be used without requiring substantial assembly.
Wikipedia has a page for <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> which uses a slightly different meaning (e.g. that a campaign can be a lengthy adventure).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> often offer pre-made gameplay structures through <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style>. Early examples include "The Keep on the Borderlands", "Rahasia", and "Ravenloft" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and "The Rise of R'lyeh" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>. Later examples include "Orcbusters", "Me and My Shadow, Mark IV", and "Send in the Clones" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style> as well as "100 Bushels of Rye" and "The Staff of Fanon" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">HÃ¢rnmaster</link></style>. "Botbusters" and "The Harder They Clone" are examples of mini-adventures for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style> while "An ARD Day's Night" and "Whitewash" are even shorter and in practice impossible to complete for the same game.

<style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> are typical used as a format in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>. Two patterns are commonly used as parts of <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style>: <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style>. The former provides goals and promises of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> for achieving those goals while the latter are used to contextualize actions and events that are part of an <style="CurrentLink">Adventure</style>.

<style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> are quite often used as parts of <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style>, especially when <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> change.

As have been said above, <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style>. Like their use in <style="Link"><link="campaigns">Campaigns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="finale-levels">Finale Levels</link></style> can be used in <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> to structurally create more tense situations where conflicts are brought to a head.

<style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> are <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. When several of them are designed to be played in sequence they can create <style="Link"><link="campaigns">Campaigns</link></style>, as for example is the case with the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> series of <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> beginning with "G1 Steading of the Hill Giant Chief" and progresses through five more (G2, G3, D1, D2, D3) before ending with "Q1 Queen of the Demonweb Pits".

The presence of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> allow <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> to be adjusted to better fit players' wishes as well as help save the overarching narratives when players have done actions which make the original structure impossible (or when the players simply are stuck and neither gameplay nor narration progresses).

<style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style> in games which allow different players to experience specific <style="CurrentLink">Adventures</style> independently of each other but later let them play together. The most likely scenario for this is when players are allowed to bring <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> from one group of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Game</link></style> to another.
